articles.headline: Europe Faces Tough Road on Effort to Ease Greek Debt
articles.snippet: Responding to a French proposal to give Greek banks more time to repay loans as they come due, the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s warned it would amount to a default.
articles.abstract: Responding to a French proposal to give Greek banks more time to repay loans as they come due, the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s warned it would amount to a default.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As Europe turns from its latest short-term fix for Greece to planning a longer-term bailout for the debt-plagued country, the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s indicated Monday how difficult it would be to offload some of the cost of rescuing Greece onto creditors without also provoking a default that could shock the global economy.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Who’s on the Family Tree? Now It’s Complicated
articles.snippet: The once-simple concept of a family tree has grown complicated in the wake of sperm donations, surrogate mothers, adoptions and relationships outside wedlock.
articles.abstract: The once-simple concept of a family tree has grown complicated in the wake of sperm donations, surrogate mothers, adoptions and relationships outside wedlock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Laura Ashmore and Jennifer Williams are sisters. After that, their relationship becomes more complex.

articles.headline: Argentina Hopes for a Big Payoff in Its Shale Oil Field Discovery
articles.snippet: The widening use of new techniques to extract oil from shale is expected to help produce petroleum in other countries, as well.
articles.abstract: The widening use of new techniques to extract oil from shale is expected to help produce petroleum in other countries, as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just east of Argentina’s Andean foothills, an oil field called the Vaca Muerta — “dead cow” in English — has finally come to life.

articles.headline: An Agency Builder, but Not Yet Its Leader
articles.snippet: Opposition to naming Elizabeth Warren as chief of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been blunted by concerns that President Obama has yet to name anyone for the post.
articles.abstract: Opposition to naming Elizabeth Warren as chief of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been blunted by concerns that President Obama has yet to name anyone for the post.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is conventional wisdom in this town that the first director of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will be anyone but Elizabeth Warren.

articles.headline: Profit Lag May Dampen Stock Rally
articles.snippet: In a lackluster economy, the stock market and corporate profits have been two bright spots. That could change with a string of earnings reports in coming weeks.
articles.abstract: In a lackluster economy, the stock market and corporate profits have been two bright spots. That could change with a string of earnings reports in coming weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this less-than-sparkling economy, Americans have at least been able to look to the rising stock market and corporate America’s robust profits as two bright spots, but even these may now be dimming.

articles.headline: Time in House Could Be Short for Republican Newcomers
articles.snippet: At least half a dozen potential primary challengers are considering a run, and there is heated chatter about more.
articles.abstract: At least half a dozen potential primary challengers are considering a run, and there is heated chatter about more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just when freshman House Republicans have finally learned their way to the Cannon Caucus Room, how to vote on a motion to proceed and which commissary serves the best tuna sandwiches, someone back home — worse, someone from their own party — wants to take it all away.

articles.headline: Hackers Select a New Target: Other Hackers
articles.snippet: In a fractious free-for-all, rival hackers engage in tit-for-tat attacks on each other, often for no better reason than to outwit the other guy.
articles.abstract: In a fractious free-for-all, rival hackers engage in tit-for-tat attacks on each other, often for no better reason than to outwit the other guy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hackers, calling themselves the A-Team, assembled a trove of private information and put it online for all to see: names, aliases, addresses, phone numbers, even details about family members and girlfriends.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Spies Tied to Slaying of a Journalist
articles.snippet: Intelligence showed that senior officials of the spy agency directed the attack on a journalist in an effort to silence criticism, two senior administration officials said.
articles.abstract: Intelligence showed that senior officials of the spy agency directed the attack on a journalist in an effort to silence criticism, two senior administration officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Obama administration officials believe that Pakistan’s powerful spy agency ordered the killing of a Pakistani journalist who had written scathing reports about the infiltration of militants in the country’s military, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A City’s Wrenching Budget Choices
articles.snippet: Wilmington, N.C., is typical of hundreds of American cities where relentless yearly cuts have slowly arrested civic momentum.
articles.abstract: Wilmington, N.C., is typical of hundreds of American cities where relentless yearly cuts have slowly arrested civic momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, N.C. — When Engine 5 pulled up to a burning house on Woodlawn Avenue early on March 19, the firefighters were told that a man might be trapped in the back left bedroom. As two firemen trained a hose toward that corner, Capt. Don Ragavage crawled through smoke and flames to search for the missing resident.

articles.headline: Scandal Grows Over Hacking of Girl’s Cell
articles.snippet: The British opposition leader said that a top executive of the News Corporation should “consider her conscience” after new disclosures.
articles.abstract: The British opposition leader said that a top executive of the News Corporation should “consider her conscience” after new disclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Political pressure is bearing down on Rebekah Brooks, a top executive of the News Corporation in Britain, following allegations that one of the company’s newspapers hacked the cellphone of a 13-year-old girl who was abducted and murdered in 2002, when Ms. Brooks was its editor.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Eric Pfanner

articles.headline: Portugal’s Debt Rating Cut to Junk by Moody’s
articles.snippet: Portugal’s new rating raises pressure on euro zone nations to work out a lasting solution to their financial woes.
articles.abstract: Portugal’s new rating raises pressure on euro zone nations to work out a lasting solution to their financial woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moody’s Investors Service cut Portugal’s debt rating to junk status on Tuesday, ratcheting up the pressure on euro zone governments to work out a lasting solution to their financial woes.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Liz Alderman
